particular cnav is a particular bundle
and what that bundles up is a few
different things so
the first thing is a bundle json which
essentially contains the
metadata of your application
so things like author version
description
um that sort of stuff would be contained
in the bundle json
um there's a thing called an invocation
image which
is a container image and essentially
this is a
container image that you point at an
environment
um and you tell it to stand up your
application
uh and from there it's able to do
whatever steps necessary i mean i mean
we're talking you know beyond turing
complete here this is like any it's a
container image it's written in any
language you would like using any
framework you like and is able to stand
up
your application against any target
environment so your target environment
could be an orchestrator here
it could be a cloud provider like aws um
and the invocation image is able to
stand up your environment
um service images are also packed
packaged up into the bundle here
so um service images would be those
things that we were talking about
earlier so
let's say you have you know your api
container image and your worker
container image and
a database you would like the package up
or you can tell your
invocation image you would like to use
your cloud provider's
database as a service offering instead
all of this can be specified using a
combination of the bundle json
and the the
service images and the invocation image
and the last thing it will say here is
cnab is parameterized and so what that
means you know in contrast to
earlier attempts with docker compose
where there was an ability to override
parameters that were specified as
environment variables in the compose
format
but it wasn't very clear which things
were
um external user facing or configurable
at ops parameters
versus which things were internal
implementation details that really you
shouldn't be overriding
um so with cnab cnub makes that very
explicit what things
are parameters that are exposed to the
person deploying the application at
deploy time
and even has some some good type systems
and checks on that so you can set
boundary conditions on your parameters
as well you can set typing
like selectable types integers etc
so all of those are the basic components
of cnab
and so as we discussed cnav is usable

applications but you can also set it use

other things um so setting up a cloud

from um what were before

docker wanted the ability to

as i said we have our manifest here

the configuration and the um the

the file system layers that make up a

so an index is kind of a manifest of
manifest
importantly what the index format added
on top of the original
multi-arch image format was generic

so these are essentially a collection of
key value pairs that you can use to
specify
whatever additional information you want
in this artifact
and thanks to that we've seen you know

that's a nice feature that allows you

recursively you can build
